title: 104_s598
content:
The Act titled "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increases taxes on tobacco products. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increases taxes on cigars. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 raises the tax rate on cigars to $5.8125 per thousand and imposes a tax of 65.875 percent on large cigars weighing more than 3 pounds per thousand, capped at $155 per thousand. The tax rates on cigars and cigarettes are being increased. For large cigars weighing over 3 pounds per thousand, a tax of 65.875 percent of the selling price, up to $155 per thousand, will be imposed. Cigarette taxes will also be raised to $62 per thousand. The tax rates on cigarettes are being increased to $130.20 per thousand. The tax on cigarette papers is amended to 3.875 cents, and the tax on cigarette tubes is amended to 1.5 cents. The tax rates on smokeless tobacco products are being increased. Cigarette tubes will now have a tax rate of 7.75 cents, snuff will have a tax rate of $1.86, and chewing tobacco will have a tax rate of 62 cents. The tax rates on smokeless tobacco products are being increased. The tax rates for pipe tobacco and chewing tobacco are being amended to 62 cents and $3.4875 respectively, effective after December 31, 1995. The excise tax rates for various tobacco products were amended, including cigars, cigarettes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco. A tax of $1.86 per pound is imposed on roll-your-own tobacco manufactured or imported into the United States. The tax rate for roll-your-own tobacco in the United States is $1.86 per pound. The term "roll-your-own tobacco" refers to tobacco suitable for making cigarettes based on its appearance, type, packaging, or labeling. The tax rate for roll-your-own tobacco in the United States is $1.86 per pound. Roll-your-own tobacco is suitable for making cigarettes and may be purchased by consumers. Technical amendments include adding roll-your-own tobacco to the code sections. The tax rate for roll-your-own tobacco in the United States is $1.86 per pound. Amendments to the code sections allow individuals to produce cigars, cigarettes, smokeless tobacco, pipe tobacco, or roll-your-own tobacco for personal consumption. Amendments to the tax code include changes to chapter 52 on tobacco products and cigarette papers and tubes. The table of chapters in the tax code is updated to reflect these amendments. Chapter 52 on tobacco products and cigarette papers and tubes is amended. The changes apply to roll-your-own tobacco removed after December 31, 1995. A transitional rule is provided for manufacturers engaged in business before the enactment of the Act. The Act allows manufacturers of roll-your-own tobacco or importers of tobacco products/cigarette papers/tubes who applied before January 1, 1996, to continue their business while awaiting final action on their application under Chapter 52 of the tax code. The Act permits manufacturers of roll-your-own tobacco or importers of tobacco products/cigarette papers/tubes to continue business while awaiting final action on their application under Chapter 52 of the tax code. All provisions of Chapter 52 apply to the applicant as if they held a permit to engage in such business. Floor stocks of certain tobacco products are subject to tax if removed before January 1, 1996. On tobacco products held for sale before January 1, 1996, the following taxes apply:
(A) Small cigars: $4.6875 per thousand for cigars weighing not more than 3 pounds per thousand.
(B) Large cigars: 53.125% of the price for which sold, not exceeding $125 per thousand for cigars weighing more than 3 pounds per thousand.
(C) Small cigarettes: $50 per thousand for cigarettes weighing not more than 3 pounds per thousand. On cigarettes, the tax is $50 per thousand for small cigarettes weighing not more than 3 pounds per thousand, and $105 per thousand for large cigarettes weighing more than 3 pounds per thousand. Cigarette papers are taxed at 3.125. Cigarette papers are taxed at 3.125 cents for each 50 papers or fraction thereof, with an exception for papers measuring more than 6 1/2 inches in length. Cigarette tubes are taxed at 6.25 cents for each 50 tubes or fraction thereof, with a similar exception for tubes measuring more than 6 1/2 inches in length. On snuff, the tax is $1.50 per pound and a proportionate tax on fractional parts. On chewing tobacco, the tax is 50 cents per pound with a similar proportionate tax on fractional parts. On chewing tobacco, the tax is 50 cents per pound with a proportionate tax on fractional parts. Pipe tobacco is taxed at $2.8125 per pound with a similar proportionate tax on fractional parts. Liabilities for the tax and payment methods are specified for various tobacco products. The tax imposed on chewing tobacco, pipe tobacco, and other tobacco products on January 1, 1996, must be paid by February 15, 1996, following the same payment method as other tobacco products. The tax on cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco removed on January 1, 1996, must be paid according to the definitions provided in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The taxes imposed on certain tobacco products are outlined in subsections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. An exception is made for retail stocks held on January 1, 1996. Foreign trade zones are also addressed, allowing for specific tobacco products to be exempt from certain laws. The Act of June 18, 1934 exempts certain tobacco products from taxes and customs duties if requested before January 1, 1996. Certain tobacco products exempt from taxes and customs duties if requested before January 1, 1996, and entered into the US from a foreign trade zone. This includes cigars, cigarettes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco under customs supervision. Certain tobacco products exempt from taxes and customs duties if requested before January 1, 1996, and entered into the US from a foreign trade zone will be subject to tax and treated as being held for sale on January 1, 1996. Chewing tobacco and pipe tobacco are treated as being held for sale on January 1, 1996. A trust fund is established under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for certain tobacco products. A trust fund is established under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for certain tobacco products, including chewing tobacco and pipe tobacco, treated as being held for sale on January 1, 1996. SEC. 9512 pertains to the Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund is created in the Treasury, funded by 3% of revenue increases from tobacco amendments. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund, established by the Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995, allocates funds for assisting farmers in transitioning from tobacco to other crops and supporting communities and individuals involved in tobacco production. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund provides assistance to farmers and communities transitioning from tobacco to other crops through grants, loans, and economic diversification plans. This includes government purchase of tobacco allotments to support those who choose to terminate their involvement in tobacco production. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund supports farmers and communities transitioning from tobacco to other crops through grants, loans, and economic diversification plans.
